repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Information and Communication
            Technologies Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Information and
            Communication Technologies (ICT) Sector Development Project
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was negligible to low; Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory; borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: a
            government that is embracing the concept of information
            society may not necessarily be ready to take the policy
            decisions that such a concept implies in terms of sector
            liberalization, private sector participation, level playing
            field competition, freedom of expression, and access to
            information and the Internet. ICT for disabled children and
            adults is an important issue that can be successfully
            addressed if a Government is committed to making a genuine
            difference for this group. The key elements of success of
            this initiative were the existence of a policy for the
            sector, the availability of excellent statistics on this
            target group that enabled customization of this program, and
            the leveraging on Non Government Organizations (NGOs) that,
            while not fully independent provided a better follow-up on
            this activity than would have been the case if the activity
            had been placed under a government department. A
            technology-based project requires flexibility and capacities
            in the field. The appraisal did not capture the flexibility
            needed in a technology project well enough. This project
            showed that planning costs of ICT acquisition of equipments
            and applications more than one year in advance is likely to
            bring inaccurate budget evaluation.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Information and Communication
            Technologies Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Information and Communication
            Technologies Project will assist in the development of
            Tunisia's Information and Communications Technology
            (ICT) sector by supporting ICT institutional and sector
            reforms, improving its e-security mechanisms, in developing
            e-government applications, and, by promoting the
            participation of the private sector in ICT development. The
            four project components will: 1) assist in the development
            of an information and communications strategy, policy, and
            regulation. In particular, the component will elaborate a
            strategic long-term plan for developing the ICT sector,
            including a strategy for the promotion of universal access,
            and assist in the award of additional licenses, including
            assistance to the telecommunications regulatory authority;
            2) formulate an e-government benchmarking, and strategy,
            being coordinated by the State Secretariat for
            Administrative Reform (Secretariat d'Etat a la Rbforme
            Administrative - SERA), and, develop e-government
            applications and online services in the Government's
            ministries and agencies, i.e., the Ministry of Justice and
            Human Rights (portal and on-line services), the Ministry of
            Culture, Youth, and Leisure (portal and on-line promotion),
            and the Ministry o f Communication Technologies and
            Transport (virtual ICT library). The component will also
            provide solutions to equip selected schools, and social
            service centers with specialized information technology (IT)
            solutions for the disabled, and, assist in the development
            of an Arabic Domain Name System (DNS) registry. ICT training
            shall increase capacities by providing a distance-learning
            platform; 3) develop and implement a computer
            risk-prevention strategy, based on the Computer Emergency
            Response Team (CERT) model, and, strengthen e-security
            research and training capacity. A data backup center will be
            established to ensure the continuity of the
            government's critical computer applications; and, 4)
            provide technical assistance (TA) for the implementation of
            a fast-paced project, with emphasis on results by the 2005
            World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS). It will
            include TA to strengthen the Project Management Unit (PMU),
            to support an ICT statistical and economic analysis unit,
            will develop and implement monitoring and evaluation
            activities, measure progress in the sector, and, publish a
            regular monitoring and evaluation report. It includes
            procurement, IT equipment, and services, and, training.

            Technologies Sector Development Project
